Harry Potter.Action: Wakes up early and joins friends and family despite discomfort from scar pain.
Engages warmly with Hermione and Ron in a friendly, casual manner.
Asks a direct question about the strange situation with the old boot and the Portkey, showing curiosity and engagement.
Listens attentively to the introduction and dialogue among adults without interrupting or showing confusion.
Relies on others to explain unfamiliar magical objects (e.g., needing Fred and George to explain the Portkey), showing limited prior knowledge in this context.
Nods sheepishly and accepts Cedric's help to get up after falling from the Portkey
Thanks Cedric politely after being helped
Looks around fascinated and smiles upon seeing the magical surroundings
Asks clarifying questions about the Portkey instead of ignoring unfamiliar magical objects.
Maintains composure after a disorienting Portkey arrival, quickly getting to his feet despite dizziness.
Nods sheepishly when helped up by Cedric, showing polite humility rather than embarrassment.
Expresses fascination and curiosity at the new environment, showing engagement and open-mindedness.
Stops to look carefully beyond immediate surroundings, taking in situational details.
Follows Arthur Weasley's instructions immediately by drawing his wand without question.
Looks puzzled by the presence of Death Eaters and masked wizards but does not panic or act rashly.
Draws his wand immediately without hesitation when confronted with danger.
Looks puzzled by the presence of Death Eaters and masked wizards, showing some initial confusion.
Follows Mr. Weasley's instructions to stick together and use the Portkey, showing obedience and situational awareness.
Struggles to rise and continues moving despite being trampled and injured in the crowd.
Shows distress observing a tear-streaked child wailing from the devastation.
Stumbles, falls, struggles to rise, is trampled and struck hard, losing consciousness.
Even while injured and partially unconscious, his blurry POV shows him trying to observe and process the unfolding dangerous events (Dark Mark, approaching figure).
Stays alert and cautious when an unknown man approaches through smoke, trying to see his face.
Listens to Hermione and Ron calling him and pays attention to their concern.
Watches the tension and danger around him without causing panic, cooperates with others.
Responds with questions calmly when accused, shows willingness to understand rather than react aggressively.
Reaches for his wand and tries to see through the smoke to identify the approaching man.
Appears confused about the crime being referred to, asking 'Crime?'
Considers and discusses the threat of Voldemort and his followers thoughtfully and seriously.
Speculates openly about the mysterious man who appeared, showing openness and honesty about his uncertainty.
Offers to get candy for Ron when he hesitates, showing friendly consideration.
Identifies the Dark Mark and makes connection to Voldemort and his followers after observing the situation carefully.
Admits uncertainty about the mysterious man he saw, showing awareness of his limits.
Smiles kindly when taking Cho's treat.
Frowns feeling guilty about something Ron did.
Does not communicate his pain or fears openly despite Hermione's concern.
Rolls up parchment and sends message via Hedwig to Sirius, showing trust and seeking connection.
Rolls up the parchment, fixes it to Hedwig, and confidently sends the message to Sirius.
Feels guilty and frowns when Cho Chang approaches but does not engage confidently.
Denies being hungry when offered food, showing some social awkwardness or distraction.
Watches every move of Mad-Eye Moody fascinated, showing attentiveness and curiosity about an experienced Auror.
Comments 'I don’t think it's pumpkin juice,' displaying observational skill and a tendency to notice details others might miss.
Maintains composure when the killing curse is demonstrated and notices Moody's wary observation of him.
Gives Neville a short warning whistle to alert him to danger, demonstrating awareness and quick thinking.
Nods and smiles knowingly at Ron's hopeful remark about being chosen for the tournament, showing friendly camaraderie.
Responds to Ron's wish about being chosen with 'Better you than me,' a light-hearted, somewhat self-deprecating comment indicating approachable modesty and good nature.
Responds lightly and confidently to Ron's wish about the Tournament selection, showing composure about his own potential involvement.
Does not react with undue fear or anxiety to the mention of dangers (splinching) involved in the Tournament, maintaining a calm demeanor.
Passively listens to the conversation about the Ageing Potion and Fred and George's prank without interjecting or challenging the logic.
Rises stiffly and walks slowly to the front to face being chosen as a champion after his name is unexpectedly called.
Clearly states to Dumbledore that he did not put his name into the Goblet of Fire and denies asking another to do so despite suspicion around him.
Accepts being a Triwizard Champion despite objections and the danger involved.
Accepts the binding magical contract to participate as a Triwizard Champion despite not entering voluntarily.
Defends himself calmly when Ron accuses him, tries to clarify the situation without hostility.
Does not escalate conflict with Ron despite tension, remains sincere in admitting confusion and lack of control.
Shows frustration with Ron's hostility by telling him to 'piss off', indicating a momentary lapse in tolerance.
Expresses frustration over the situation but tries to clarify he did not seek out the challenge or eternal glory.
Admits to not understanding exactly what happened with the Goblet of Fire, showing some vulnerability and lack of knowledge about key events.
Stands his ground during a tense exchange with Ron, demonstrating emotional resilience and a measure of assertiveness.
Corrects Rita Skeeter patiently when she gets his age wrong.
Endures being trapped in a broom cupboard by Rita Skeeter with tolerance.
Flustered and somewhat uncomfortable with Rita Skeeter's probing questions, does not engage in self-aggrandizement, responds simply and honestly.
Does not correct mistaken assumptions aggressively, keeps calm despite insinuations about his character and motives.
Somewhat passive during the interview, allowing others to speak for him or manipulate the narrative (Rita Skeeter).
Struggles to confidently articulate his feelings and situation during the interview, appearing flustered and uncertain.
Maintains composure despite provocation by Rita Skeeter's aggressive and manipulative questioning.
Sits alone burdened, carefully attaches a message to owl for Sirius, showing trust and responsibility.
Sits alone, looking burdened and contemplative while preparing to communicate securely with Sirius using a weathered piece of parchment tied to an owl's leg.
Carefully takes the weathered bit of parchment and seems attentive to the message under potentially stressful conditions.
Throws the Daily Prophet newspaper into the fire, expressing anger at Rita Skeeter's portrayal of him.
Acknowledges his insecurities about being less skilled in magic compared to other champions and reflects on what his father might have done.
Responds grimly and briefly to Sirius's congratulations, showing restrained emotional openness.
Hurls the newspaper into the fire in frustration but remains composed and wary of the fire's reaction.
Expresses self-doubt about his magical skills compared to others and his capability as a fourth year.
Listens to Sirius's advice and reflects on what his father would have done, showing thoughtful consideration.
Shows concern about his readiness and acknowledges his limitations.
Listens seriously and respectfully to Sirius’ warnings and advice.
Exhibits vulnerability and uncertainty about facing dangers ahead.
Does not dismiss or boast about his situation, showing sincerity.
Acknowledges he does not know as much magic as others and admits he is not ready for the upcoming challenges.
Listens carefully to Sirius’s advice about his limitations and the dangers ahead.
Shows signs of fear and uncertainty about the tasks he must face, indicating a lack of confidence.
Shields the fire to protect and confront the approaching figure (Ron).
Dismisses Ron’s concern by suggesting he is imagining things.
Starts to make things up to smooth over the tension with Ron but is interrupted.
Engages in light teasing with Neville about his book.
Responds to Hermione’s message to relay information to Ron, but does so indirectly through Hermione, showing mild avoidance.
Wheels around quickly to shield the fire from a shadowy figure, demonstrating alertness and protective instinct.
Dismisses Ron's suspicion by suggesting Ron is imagining things, showing a slightly defensive or evasive response.
Begins to make things up when caught off guard by Ron, indicating a momentary lapse in straightforwardness and confidence.
Engages in conversation about Neville's book and the scene around him, maintaining awareness of his environment.
Displays mild frustration or correction towards Neville's behavior in conversation, suggesting an attentive and perceptive mind.
Recognizes and responds appropriately to Hermione's message about Hagrid looking for him, showing social receptiveness and openness.
Follows Hagrid into the Forbidden Forest despite feeling uneasy and queasy.
Asks Hagrid questions about the dragons and the task, showing curiosity and engagement.
Angry about the 'POTTER STINKS' badges but controls his anger, does not retaliate aggressively.
Approaches Cedric Diggory calmly to discuss the upcoming task despite the tension and competition.
Nods silently to confirm information, showing sincere communication without boasting or dismissiveness.
Does not confront or mock Cedric or his friends despite the social antagonism evident from the badges.
Recognizes Madame Maxime and Karkaroff quickly in a tense situation, showing awareness and observation skills.
Appears angry and emotionally affected by other students' negative badges against him, indicating some emotional reaction but does not lose composure visibly.
Initiates a calm and focused conversation with Cedric Diggory about the upcoming dragon task, demonstrating seriousness and proactive planning.
Tells Cedric information he believes is right to share despite potential awkwardness.
Effectively deflects Draco Malfoy’s taunts with a confident and witty insult.
Stays assertive and confident when confronting Ron about personal boundaries.
Avoids engaging in Malfoy’s provocation beyond a sharp retort, showing emotional control.
Turns away from Malfoy after confrontation, does not escalate conflict
Watches events unfold without intervening immediately in Moody and Malfoy exchange
Spins quickly when hearing the shout, immediately locating Moody and Malfoy with his eyes, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Remains calm and observant during the chaos initiated by Moody's sudden intervention.
Does not intervene violently or escalate the situation himself, deferring to the authority of Moody and McGonagall.
Follows Moody obediently into his office without hesitation, showing respect for authority and readiness to engage with further instruction.
Did a decent thing by helping Diggory despite him being competition.
Questions Professor Moody about talking strategy, showing sincerity and hesitance about cheating.
Nods uncertainly when Moody explains the Foe-Glass; asks whether discussing Diggory's situation is appropriate, showing hesitation and lack of confidence.
Does a decent thing for Diggory, showing thoughtfulness and generosity despite competition.
Shows vague understanding and lack of clear plan when Moody asks about the dragon task, giving a hesitant and incomplete answer.
Listens to Moody's strategic advice about other champions and opponents.
Watches Ron studying alone and observes Hermione pushing through whispering girls, showing awareness and a friendly, inclusive attitude.
Scowls and imitates Hermione briefly, indicating light-heartedness and rapport with friends.
Responds to Moody about his flying skills candidly and without boasting.
Ducks a book Hermione flings, showing playful interaction.
Corrects Draco’s false statement about him, implicitly showing sincerity.
Does not confront Hermione directly after her obliviousness to Draco’s slur, indicating tolerance or avoiding conflict.
Expresses mild frustration about Moody not telling him something directly, showing some impatience but understandable given the context.
Acknowledges his flying ability and hears positive remarks about it from Moody.
Expresses frustration about restrictions (not allowed a broom) but understands he has his wand and wits.
Ducks a flying book and remains aware of surroundings, showing alertness and quick reflexes.
Does not respond to Malfoy's provocation about him crying, showing restraint or reluctance to engage.
Feels unsure why Moody doesn't communicate things directly, indicating some confusion or impatience.
Defends Hermione against Malfoy's taunts by denying false claims.
Shows vulnerability by admitting to crying alone at night about his parents.
Reacts to Hermione's anger and concern after being hit by a book with some pain but no retaliation.
Allows Hermione to show concern and accepts comfort from her (Hermione throwing her arms around him).
Keeps focus and composure despite tense situation (pacing, nodding when asked how he feels).
Paces nervously but shows willingness to face the dragon in the upcoming task.
Remains composed and attentive during the announcement of the tasks, showing respect towards others despite the high tension.
Does not interrupt or protest when the dangerous task is explained, demonstrating trust in the organizers and tolerance of the situation.
Shows no visible sign of fear or selfishness, standing with the other champions patiently.
Quietly observes the announcement of the first task and its details, listens attentively without asking unnecessary questions.
Does not display immediate panic or indecision upon the daunting announcement of facing a dangerous dragon in the task.
Does not proactively seek further clarification immediately after the task explanation, possibly missing a chance to better understand the details.
Uses Accio to summon his Firebolt quickly and efficiently.
Rockets into the air confidently on his broomstick despite the danger.
Swoops and dives skillfully to avoid the Horntail's flames.
Rolls sideways to avoid the dragon's spiked tail and handles the broom tightly.
Keeps focused and courageous during the dangerous dragon task, risking himself to secure the golden egg.
Notes Cho's rapt attention and seems aware of her presence during the task.
Skillfully dodges the dragon's fire and tail attacks, expertly maneuvers his broom to evade danger, and successfully retrieves the golden egg despite injury.
Shows brief distraction by noticing Cho, which leads to being hit by the dragon's tail.
Grins despite others jeering after opening the egg, showing good-natured tolerance of teasing.
Responds with sarcasm to Ron's admission that others accused him behind his back, indicating some hurt but not hostility.
Acknowledges warnings from friends about dangers and seems to accept their concern.
Responds subtly to Cho's glance and twin girls' greetings with modesty and slight embarrassment (porridge down chin, dabbing mouth)
Interacts amicably with peers like Parvati and Padma, responds politely to greetings
Shrugs with Hermione after awkward situation with Nigel the first year, showing tolerance and good-natured patience
Responds to Cho's glance with casual behavior but quickly tries to maintain composure by dabbing his mouth with his napkin.
Does not engage in or react defensively to the gossip and headline about his 'secret heartache' in the Daily Prophet.
Allows others (Parvati and Padma) to approach and greet him confidently in a social setting.
Does not take visible action or assert himself when Ron and Hermione discuss his personal matters publicly.
Asks Professor McGonagall about the Yule Ball and shows curiosity about dancing with a girl.
Asks Professor McGonagall about the Yule Ball and the requirement to dance, showing curiosity and willingness to understand expectations.
Seemingly confused or surprised about the tradition of dancing at the Yule Ball, indicating uncertainty or unfamiliarity with social customs.
Grins with Ron about Neville’s situation, responding lightly to his friend's gloom.
Responds skeptically but without malice when Ron doubts Hermione’s claim about having a date.
Does not tease or mock Hermione for her withering response or for going with someone unknown to them.
Grins with Ron despite social awkwardness about dates, showing social confidence.
Dismisses Hermione's claim about having a date without evidence, showing skepticism and confidence.
Makes no obvious mistakes or shows confusion in the social scenario, maintaining composure.
Does not take initiative to improve his own dating situation despite the conversation about the ball.
Nods hesitantly to partner-up plan, showing willingness to cooperate despite reservations.
Compliments Cho on the scenery sincerely despite feeling awkward.
Politely thanks Cho for a warning about icy stairs, showing attentiveness and appreciation.
Asks Cho to go to the Ball with him in an earnest, somewhat nervous manner.
Responds gracefully to Cho's rejection without bitterness or rudeness, saying 'No problem' and looking away to hide discomfort.
Hesitates before agreeing to have partners in the common room.
Messes up asking Cho to the ball, initially speaking incoherently and struggling to collect himself.
Recovers quickly after Cho rejects him and handles the rejection with composure and maturity.
Sits calmly in the common room and listens attentively to friends discussing their social interactions.
Shows empathy and concern by asking what happened to Ron after he appears shaken.
Does not interrupt conversations or behave impulsively during the discussion about Ron and Fleur Delacour.
Reacts with some surprise and curiosity to Ron's social awkwardness, but remains composed.
Tries to come up with an idea to help a situation.
Shares a light-hearted moment with Ron about dress robes, showing friendly banter.
Raises an eyebrow appraisingly at Parvati's comment, showing engagement and politeness.
Confidently chooses simple, unadorned dress robes rather than ostentatious ones, showing self-assurance and clarity in decision-making.
Keeps calm and thoughtfully considers Hermione's feelings and social dynamics (understands why she might be upset and reluctant to share her plans).
Raises an eyebrow appraisingly when Parvati approaches, showing social awareness and composed demeanor.
Nods glumly and observes others without mockery or negativity.
Waves to Hermione with a little smile as she acknowledges him.
Raises his hand to Parvati's waist and dances despite feeling awkward and out of place, manages to smile during the dance.
Scans the room and acknowledges others' presence (Ron, Hermione with Krum) without jealousy or negative reaction.
Responds promptly to Parvati's command to take her waist and begins to dance despite feeling out of place.
Feels self-conscious and clumsy while dancing but manages to smile and continue.
Shifts eyes from Cho and Cedric's gyrating figures, shows attentive observation without judgment.
Sits watching grimly with Ron, sharing in subdued mood.
Makes a lighthearted comment about Krum going to the library, showing friendly teasing.
Stares incredulously at Ron when accused, not hostile but surprised.
Drifts alone in courtyard, quietly observing Snape and Karkaroff without confrontation.
Stops and listens carefully to the conversation between Snape and Karkaroff by hiding behind a gargoyle.
Incredulously stares at Ron after hearing his suggestion but does not immediately confront or act on it.
Responds sarcastically to Hermione's question, indicating a casual or dismissive attitude towards an important task.
Acknowledges that Viktor has figured out the egg puzzle, showing awareness of others' competence.
Engages in social interaction confidently with Cedric Diggory, responding 'Spectacular' to a greeting.
Does not demonstrate active effort to solve the egg riddle despite Hermione's worry and urging, suggesting lack of preparation for an impending challenge.
Recognizes Moaning Myrtle and greets her casually and without hostility.
Keeps to himself while dealing with the egg, shows no signs of impatience or anger.
Navigates a risky, unstable staircase carefully to avoid falling while clutching the egg.
Enters the Prefects' bathroom and discovers how to activate the emerald tap to fill the bath, showing resourcefulness and quick learning.
Quickly snaps shut the egg when a painful screeching wail emits, demonstrating presence of mind and control under distress.
Expresses confusion and doubts about his own sanity when seeing the colored water and hearing the wail, indicating some uncertainty.
Listens patiently to Moaning Myrtle and attempts to solve the riddle in the egg.
Responds politely and cooperatively to Myrtle's teasing remarks without irritation.
Focuses on the puzzle rather than being distracted by Myrtle’s flirtatious behavior.
Collaborates closely with Ron and Hermione on solving the mystery, showing trust and inclusiveness.
Expresses concern and admits his limitation about holding breath for an hour underwater.
Recognizes and interprets the clue from the egg's singing about the Black Lake.
Expresses doubt and realistic concern about holding his breath underwater for an hour, showing awareness of his limits.
Engages in problem-solving discussion with Hermione and Ron about the upcoming task.
Dismisses Neville's attempts to share information about plants bluntly and shows irritation ('I don't care about Mandrakes! I don't care about gravity-resistant trees!')
Watches Neville go without further engagement, does not encourage or show tolerance for his enthusiasm
Frowns and watches others leave without engaging, showing a reserved and somewhat distracted demeanor.
Responds brusquely and dismisses Neville's enthusiastic sharing of knowledge without considering potential usefulness.
Eventually listens to Neville's helpful suggestion about Gillyweed despite initial impatience.
Asks Neville questions about the Gillyweed to ensure he can breathe underwater, showing trust and reliance on a friend.
Takes the Gillyweed and chews it despite evident danger, showing determination and willingness to trust others (Neville) for help.
Struggles underwater to save others despite danger, shows determination and concern.
Adapts to underwater breathing by developing gills and webbed hands and feet, skillfully swims and pursues the silver light (mermaid), demonstrating quick physical and mental adaptation.
Fumbles to reach the tool lashed to his ankle when attacked by Grindylow water demons, showing momentary clumsiness under pressure.
Defends himself against Grindylows without hesitation, showing determination and focus.
After defeating threatening creatures, notices the threatening yet angry gestures of others and does not attack, demonstrating restraint.
Pursues the mermaid and resists the Siren Song to save his friends, showing care, loyalty, and selflessness.
Actively works to free his friends who are trapped underwater, exhibiting helpfulness and concern.
Snatches his wand quickly despite initial fumbling. Casts 'Incendio' spell accurately and effectively to strike and kill the Grindylow.
Continuously fires spells with precision at multiple aggressive Grindylows, adapting to their evasive maneuvers and ultimately defeats them all.
Remains calm and poised while surrounded by many Grindylows, showing readiness and wariness before they unexpectedly retreat.
Follows the mermaid after observing mysterious silver light and strange behavior, showing curiosity and determination to complete the task.
Attempts to rescue the captured friends by swimming forward and tugging at the ropes binding them.
Uses magic to free Ron from the vine, showing quick thinking and protective behavior.
Urges the mermaid to get out of the way so he can help Hermione, shows concern for Hermione as a friend.
Insists Hermione is his friend too, displaying loyalty and sincerity.
Focuses on saving friends (Ron and Hermione) without hesitation, indicating trustworthiness and good-naturedness.
Saves Gabrielle by using his wand to free her from danger in the water despite risks to himself.
Allows Neville to hug him but responds brusquely by telling him to get off.
Downplays his heroic actions by saying 'It was nothing, really...'
Uses his wand skillfully to cast Incendio and free Gabrielle from the rock underwater.
Struggles visibly during the underwater ordeal but persists until he reaches the surface.
Responds modestly and downplays his heroic actions when Fleur compliments him.
Pushes Neville away roughly after an emotional reaction.
Shows determination to rescue Mr. Weasley and others during the task, sacrificing his chance to win first place.
Determination to rescue not only Mr. Weasley but others as well during the task, causing him to finish second.
Finishes last in a task and initially downplays his performance.
Smiles softly at the sound of his friends' voices and the gentle evening breeze
Stands frozen, unmoving, when seeing a dark figure lying in the brush
Stands stunned after Moody rebukes him for being a fool and playing hero recklessly.
Smiles softly at the sound of his friends’ voices and the gentle evening breeze, showing calmness and composure amidst tension.
Grabs his scar and freezes upon sensing something dark ahead, showing heightened awareness even if he does not immediately act.
Leans forward eagerly and calls out to Dumbledore, showing engagement and respect.
Passes before Dumbledore's face with nothing (no reaction), indicating restraint or possibly discomfort.
Leans forward attentively to observe and gather information in an unfamiliar and disorienting environment.
Calls out to Dumbledore but receives no response, showing limited influence or control in the situation.
Leans forward, squinting at the young man (Barty Jr.) with a mix of curiosity and recognition in chaotic, tense circumstances.
Complies respectfully with Dumbledore's invitation, taking his hand and entering the Pensieve trance without hesitation.
Shows sincere curiosity and openness when asking about the Pensieve and Mr. Crouch's son.
Leans forward and squints at Barty Jr., trying to recognize him in the chaos.
Complies willingly with the 'Second Dumbledore' and follows him without hesitation into the Pensieve.
Expresses curiosity about the Pensieve and attempts to understand its function, showing openness to learning.
Does not interrupt Dumbledore's explanation or show impatience, indicating careful listening and respect for information.
Briefly looks away when processing new information about Barty Crouch Jr., suggesting discomfort or hesitation.
Expresses concern about danger and asks sincere, direct questions about his wellbeing and the situation.
Presses Dumbledore for answers out of anxiety and fear, showing vulnerability and trust.
Does not react with anger or blame towards Dumbledore despite feeling threatened and confused.
His focus remains on understanding and protecting others rather than self-pity.
Asks direct and critical questions about the dangers he faces and the reasons behind the Triwizard Tournament continuing, demonstrating engagement and seeking understanding.
Expresses urgency and insistence on knowing the truth about his visions and protection, showing proactive behavior.
Becomes mute and turns to exit when faced with lack of answers, possibly showing frustration but also restraint and composure.
Answers Snape respectfully and honestly when questioned about Gillyweed.
Does not escalate conflict with Snape despite Snape's hostile and accusatory tone.
Turns away silently after overhearing Snape and Karkaroff, showing restraint.
Refuses to steal from Snape's stores despite temptation or provocation.
Recognizes and confirms the ingredients (boomslang skin and lacewing flies) related to Polyjuice Potion; considers Snape's suspicions but prioritizes bigger concerns.
Voices concern about an unknown approaching threat but admits uncertainty about what it is.
Carefully considers the Maze entrance and surroundings before proceeding, showing awareness and readiness.
Moves cautiously forward at first, then breaks into a trot and finally runs when spooked by mist and rustling sounds.
Hears Fleur's scream and runs towards it immediately, showing concern.
Stops uncertainly when sees Krum, then approaches Fleur carefully, tending to her.
Does not engage or confront Krum despite Krum's odd behavior, shows tolerance and non-aggression.
Runs anxiously through the maze, keeps track of Cedric and the situation, showing concern.
Thanks Cedric after Cedric saves him by stunning Krum.
Navigates the confusing maze, remains alert, manages to slip through a closing hedge with good timing under pressure.
Runs anxiously and looks over shoulder, showing signs of being freaked and possibly overwhelmed by the situation.
Follows Cedric quickly but slows down when Cedric disappears, showing some loss of confidence or fatigue.
Ducks quickly at Cedric's shout to avoid Krum's spell, demonstrating quick reactions and awareness.
Stops running the race to help Cedric when he is caught by the snaking branches instead of continuing to try to win the prize alone.
Refuses to take the prize without Cedric, insisting they take it together despite the opportunity to claim sole victory.
Stops to help Cedric who is suffocating in the hedge despite being able to sprint toward the prize
Decides to take the Triwizard Cup together with Cedric instead of seizing it alone
Shows hesitation and torn feelings between ambition and duty
Urgently warns Cedric to get back to the Cup despite personal danger.
Clutches his scar in agony but still tries to protect Cedric.
Steadies himself silently when Voldemort orders him to bow, enduring physical pain without complaint.
Does not retaliate or show anger despite being tortured by Voldemort's Cruciatus Curse.
Remains mostly silent and composed under Voldemort's taunts and aggression.
Fires an angry rope at Voldemort after Voldemort insults his mother.
Wheels and fights back with determination despite agony.
Staggers and heads directly toward Voldemort rather than fleeing.
Stops and confronts Voldemort rather than turning his back.
Wheels and fires an angry rope spell at Voldemort with determination despite pain.
Staggers forward toward Voldemort, weaving through the trees to maintain offensive momentum.
Stops and faces Voldemort calmly, wand hanging limply before preparing to duel.
Counters Voldemort’s spell with his own simultaneous spell causing a shimmer of gold light and surprising Voldemort.
Sends protective magic beads toward Voldemort despite physical pain from wounds.
Keeps his focus to protect others even when facing tremendous personal danger and blood loss.
Tears well up as he watches the apparitions of loved ones and Cedric, showing emotional sincerity and empathy.
Nods to several requests to help take Cedric's body back to his family, accepting responsibility respectfully.
Despite pain and injury, maintains focus and continues to act under extreme pressure during the duel with Voldemort.
Successfully sends a magical bead back towards Voldemort, showcasing skill in combat magic.
Shows emotional vulnerability (tears) but still fulfills crucial tasks (listening to advice, accepting the moment to let go).
Clings to Cedric's body and insists on bringing him back instead of leaving him behind, showing deep care and respect.
Resists letting go of Cedric’s body even when urged by Dumbledore, indicating sincere loyalty to his friend.
Shows emotional vulnerability through tears at witnessing Amos Diggory's grief.
Responds silently and passively when Moody urges him away from the crowd, allowing others to care for him.
Despite emotional turmoil, quickly gets up and allows Moody to take control of the situation.
Appears vague and not fully coherent when asked to explain what happened.
Recognizes and articulates that the Triwizard Cup was a Portkey and suspects foul play.
Observes that Krum was acting strangely, possibly under the Imperius Curse, indicating perceptiveness.
Directly confronts Moody and accuses him of foul play, showing boldness and assertiveness.
Fails to initially mention the graveyard incident, potentially withholding key information.
Does not draw his wand aggressively when Moody reaches for his wand; instead shows calm, nodding to the Pensieve glass
Obeys Dumbledore's instructions promptly and steps aside without protest
Nods to the Pensieve instead of drawing his wand, showing calm and trusting judgment under pressure.
'Constant vigilance, Professor' - shows awareness and readiness through confident verbal warning.
Does not immediately react with aggression but stays composed as the scene escalates.
Relies on others (Dumbledore, Snape) to handle the situation rather than intervening directly.
Exchanges a look of trust with Snape and complies with Dumbledore's request to show his wound despite uncertainty.
Responds calmly and politely to Dumbledore's apology for putting him in danger, showing tolerance and acceptance.
Does not display any signs of bitterness or blame towards others despite dangerous circumstances.
Identifies Moody in the trunk and correctly uses the Polyjuice Potion flask given by Dumbledore.
Exchanges a meaningful look with Snape, indicating awareness and communication under pressure.
Shows uncertain hesitation when asked by Dumbledore to lift his sleeve but complies.
Expresses acceptance and calmness about being put in danger repeatedly.
Speaks quietly and sincerely about his experience battling Voldemort, showing openness and trust toward Dumbledore.
Asks concerned and thoughtful questions about the nature of death and his parents, indicating sensitivity and emotional depth.
Accepts the difficult truth that few will believe him but feels the responsibility to share it anyway, showing integrity and perseverance.
Sits solemnly and numbly during the memorial for Cedric Diggory, showing respect and shared grief.
Engages in eye contact and nods with Krum, indicating mutual respect and silent communication.
Clutches by Fleur, indicating seeking or accepting comfort in a vulnerable moment.
Sits solemnly and numbly during Dumbledore's speech, showing composure despite grief and shock.
Drifts eyes to the enchanted ceiling rather than reacting emotionally in an overt way during emotional news, indicating internal processing and self-restraint.
Does not display outward leadership or take initiative in this scene, reflecting a more passive role in group setting.
Welcomes Ron and Hermione with openness, shares a moment of reflective honesty about his difficult life when Ron says 'It's not easy being your friend,' responding 'Try being me.'
Expresses a quiet camaraderie and commitment to friendship and sticking together despite difficulties, echoing 'Together...'
